Posts.Content: nysupraman; Good timing. I haven't looked at this site for over a week. I had surgery at Cleveland Clinic 3 weeks ago. I decided surgery was the way to go and to keep me positive wanted to know I had the best going in. Cleveland Clinic is rated #1 Urology Hospital by US News. I had my consultation and surgery with Dr. Eric Klein who is also the Chairman of Urology and Professor of Surgery. He does the open surgery and has preformed over 3,000 procedures. His positive margins are less than 2% which is by far the lowest I have heard. Open is said to have more bleeding and slower recovery which is really not important when you consider they recycle the blood and I returned to work 2 weeks after surgery (I'm not overweight and in good health). I also can say I was 100% continent when the catheter was removed and remain so. I've talked to two people who had the robotic surgery at Cleveland and while they had good results were not 100% continent like me. This could be due to the individual and some I think is the surgeon. I went in Gleason 3+3 and the pathology showed negative margins but a Gleason 4+3 which is a fair amount more aggressive. The point here is not to delay the surgery potentially allowing the cancer to spread outside the prostate. You will be in good hands at Cleveland and especially Dr Klein if you chose to go with him. Let me know if you have any questions. Greg
Posts.Signature: Greg, Diagnosed 1/17/13, TIc, Gleason 3+3, 3 positive cores (5%, 0%, 50%), PSA 4.7 (7/7/12), Excellent health (otherwise) Open prostatectomy 4/15/13 by Dr. Eric Klein, Cleveland Clinic. Nerve bundles and lymph nodes in tact. Pathology showed negative margins, Gleason 4+3, 108 gram prostate.
Posts.Title: Father newly diagnosed ....

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed 2 weeks ago and I'm researching treatments. My urologist made an appointment for me with a Brachytherapy clinic to have an ultrasound on my prostate to see if it is a good candidate. According to this website Link removed per new user policy I qualify on all counts but two; no previous BPH and postate should be less than 60 grams. I've have BPH for the last 3 years and my prostate is 122 grams. I would like to not waste the time and money if I don't qualify.
Posts.Title: Do I qualify for Brachytherapy?

Posts.Content: Chuck; First; I noticed we are located not too far apart with my location in the Chicago western suburbs. Since Friday have have accomplished quite a bit. I have contacted Cleveland Clinic and will be doing a consultation with Dr. Eric klein. His assistant has requested all my doctor notes, bone scan, pathology report and the biopsy slides sent to him. Eric did my brother-in-law's prostactomy 12 years ago and as you may know is highly regarded. I will be meeting with him in the next few weeks. I was leaning to the surgery and then this morning came back on the fence after a meeting with Chicago Prostate a clinic which only does brachytherapy. Dr. Brian Moran, who I hear is also highly regarded showed me some studies and comparisons with the Cleveland Clinic. Dr. Moran does 30 brachytherapies per week and has done thousands including some from with people from other countries. He said my status is very early and projected 98% probable cure rate. He said they have no bowel issues and in the worst case a catheter for 1-2weeks. He did a DRE in the office and doesn't think my prostate is 122 grams. My report also showed 70 grams and thinks this might be close to actual. He said if I want to consider brachytherapy they would first do an ultrasound of my prostate to see if I'm a good candidate. Moran also gave me 3-4 names of excellant surgeons in the Chicago area in case I wanted to stay locally. Your suggestion rearding timing is hitting home and I will check out both treatments more throughly.
Posts.Title: Do I qualify for Brachytherapy?

Posts.Content: Here are my stats: 64 on 3/2/13, 5-11, 185#, excellent health, PSA 4.7, Gleason 3+3, 3 cores out of 14 positive (5%, 20%, 50%), T1c, prostate 122 grams
Posts.Title: Do I qualify for Brachytherapy?

Posts.Content: [QUOTE=Sarg;I agree that a cough or a sneeze is a bit of a jolt, however, if you have a small pillow, when you feel a sneeze or cough coming just hold the pillow tightly across your abdomen and it will greatly lessen that jolt. Sarg; this does help. I considered going to your surgeon looking at his experience and his location to our second home in Naples. My brother in law went to Klein 14 years ago and I liked that his was the chairman of urology at Cleveland Clinic and this was the best hence of an unbiased opinion consultation. I really don,t have pain sitting or lying down. It is only when I move during sitting, lying and walking. I'm impatient and need to give it the time it needs. Thanks for all the comments.

Posts.Title: Three days after surgery

Posts.Content: I had open surgery by Dr. Eric Klein at Cleveland Clinic. Doc said it wet well and the nerve bundles and lymph nodes were left in-tack. Out in 11/2 days and spent a night before driving 6 hours to Chicago. For people looking for an expert I recommend Dr. Klein. He is the Chairman of the #1 Urology hospital and has performed over 3,000 surgeries. So far I've had to deal with some pain when bending over and sneezing (this hurt). I'm looking forward to having the catheter removed at University of Chicago Medical to avoid the drive back and forth. For surgery patients how long did the pain take to reduce to a low level?

Posts.Title: Three days after surgery

Posts.Content: I'm in the process on deciding the treatment and I'm also a fitness adict and love golf. Would it also be several weeks before golf? Chuck; I noticed you said it was 10 days before you returned from Mayo. I'm considering the Cleveland Clinic and it is 6 hours away and plan to drive home with my wife 2-3 days later and return 8 days later for the catheter to be removed. Greg

Posts.Title: Exercising after da vinci surgery

Posts.Content: I guess I was uncomfortable and impatient. I returned to the office 2 weeks after surgery. After 2-3 days started getting sore in the groin probably from sitting too long and not walking enough. It is now 3 weeks after surgery and I'm taking 3 walks during the day and the soreness here and the midsection is at a low level. I can't wait to golf in one week!
Posts.Signature: Greg, Diagnosed 1/17/13, TIc, Gleason 3+3, 3 positive cores (5%, 0%, 50%), PSA 4.7 (7/7/12), Excellent health (otherwise) Open prostatectomy 4/15/13 by Dr. Eric Klein, Cleveland Clinic. Nerve bundles and lymph nodes in tact. Pathology showed negative margins, Gleason 4+3, 108 gram prostate.
Posts.Title: Questions regarding Open or Robotic RP recovery.

Posts.Content: I'm now on my 6th day after surgery and finding recovery slow. I had the open type and my incision is 25 staples and causes pain when going up or down while sitting and laying. I can climb stairs and slept in my bed the first night. I'm not on pain killers and haven't found much of an improvement from the beginning. Questions: How long for there to be a noticeable reduction in pain when moving? How long did it take to go back to office work? Did you find anything to help speed your recovery; walking, drinking fluids? Fortunately I'm not overweight and workout so I can't image what this would be like if I wasn't. I know of one guy who had Robotic and it was one week before he climbed stairs so slept in a recliner. I'm I impatient?
